reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “abundance and diminishing returns implies more altruistic spending” consideration (2.3.2). That point is not central to the essay’s overall conclusions (which lean heavily on skepticism about WAM-convergence and on trade/threat dynamics), and the essay itself already hedges the abundance→altruism argument and notes billionaire-giving data as only weak evidence, so even a successful refutation wouldn’t move the main thesis that much (low centrality). Still, the critique does meaningfully undercut that specific sub-argument by pointing out ungrounded assumptions about utility curvature for post-AGI/modified agents and by noting that billionaire philanthropy is a noisy proxy likely confounded by present-day constraints (moderate-low strength, partly “priced in”). The points are largely correct and clearly stated, with little fluff, and they form a single, coherent line of criticism of one section.
title: Post-scarcity altruism relies on contestable utility assumptions and weak empirical proxies
